title-group.article-title: Light-emitting fabrics integrated with structured polymer optical fibers treated with an infrared CO2 laser

contrib-group.aff: Institute of Textiles and Clothing, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong

author-notes.corresp: Professor Xiaoming Tao, Institute of Textiles and Clothing, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong. Email: tctaoxm@inet.polyu.edu.hk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper describes woven fabrics made from polymer optical fibers (POF), which are treated with a CO2 laser so that the resultant surface notches on the POFs facilitate side emission of light. The transmission and side-emitting behavior of POF with surface notches are studied in term of the variation in bending curvatures, which is related to end-usage of the woven fabrics as flexible displays, wearable phototherapy devices and fashion accessories. The measured power of transmission of light from the POF rapidly decreases with increasing bending curvature. However, the measured power of side-emission of light from the notched POFs remains almost constant at various bending curvatures within the experimental range. Theoretical analysis of the light propagation in a notched POF is conducted, which illustrates that more light is reflected from one side of the notch when the bending curvature is increased hence the transmission of the light is decreased. The theoretical and experimental results reach a good agreement.

body.p: Fabrics integrated with polymer optical fibers (POFs) are light, flat and flexible, making them easy to connect to light sources, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), and thus suitable for large-area illumination with three-dimensional (3D) manifold design possibilities.1 Hence they have attracted increasing attention and been explored for flexible, large-size and 3D displays,2,3 communication4 and sensors in fields such as medical, healthcare, architecture, fashion design, security and military, data communication and automotive engineering.5–8 All of these applications require that POFs have lateral light emission capacity at the predetermined places on the textile surface, not only at the end of the fiber.

Induced structures at the core-cladding interface or in the core of POFs change the propagation path of light and facilitate light side emission. Hence mechanical or chemical methods have been used to make controlled structural features on the surface or inside of POFs. Side notching results in simple figures of light dots, whereas surface abrasion leads to a more uniform light distribution.9,10 Alternatively, producing titled Bragg gratings, long-period gratings, super-structured fiber gratings or adding scattering particles in the fiber core also evoke light emission.11–13 Another approach is to apply fluorescent substance on the cladding of POFs.3,14

Regular patterns can be quickly and easily formed on the surface of polymer materials by laser.15 Laser micromachining with a computer graphic facility is a simple and controllable method to treat a large-sized sheet fabric made from POFs with a wide range of design possibilities, high precision, high efficiency and a contactless operation mode.16 Infrared lasers are often used to ablate the underlying material photothermally. When the focused laser beam meets the material surface, the temperature of the irradiated spot rises so rapidly that the material first melts and then decomposes and vaporizes, leaving a void in the workpiece.17 A number of groups have investigated laser ablation of polymers.18,19 Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) microfluidic systems were fabricated by a commercial CO2 laser system.20,21 Surface properties of polymer materials irradiated by CO2 laser were also studied, including polyethylene terephthalate (PET), polyethylene (PE), polyester (PES) and polyamide (PA),22–24 where the effects of laser power and processing speed on the polymer were investigated, which provides useful information on laser photothermal ablation parameters.

In order to integrate the surface-treated POFs into fabrics, textile processes such as weaving, knitting or stitching have been used.2,25 POFs are deformed any such fabrics to various extents, which depend on many factors, for example, fabric structure, yarn and fiber diameters and processing conditions. Consideration and care are normally taken to ensure that the POFs are subject to the minimum amount of mechanical deformation, thus suffering only light transmission loss. However, since the fabric rigidity is very low, bending of the fabric, followed by bending of the POFs inside the fabric, occurs in usage. Bending of POFs at the macro- and micro-scale has been dealt with using well-established theoretical treatment.26 Because the laser ablation creates surface features such as notches, grooves and ripples, bending of such surface-treated POF has not been investigated, as it alters the POF’s wave guiding properties and makes the light refract out from the POF’s side.27–29 Hence it is necessary to study the light propagation of bent POFs with surface notches created by laser from the viewpoint of light emission of POF fabrics. In this paper, by combining surface notches and woven structure, light side-emitting fabrics will be fabricated and investigated. The light transmission and side-emission behavior of POFs and the resultant fabrics under various conditions will be examined experimentally and theoretically.

sec.title: Materials and specimen preparation
sec.p: The POF used in this research was a multimode step-index fiber (ESKA™, CK10) supplied by Mitsubishi Rayon Co., Ltd. The material used for the core was PMMA (nco = 1.49), while fluorinated PMMA derivative was used as the cladding material (ncl = 1.404). It has an out diameter of 250 µm and a core of about 240 µm. The numerical aperture (NA) is 0.5.30

A commercial CO2 laser system (FLEXI-150, Marcatex, GFK, Spain) was used for laser micromachining. The pulsed CO2 laser has a wavelength of 10.6 µm and the duty cycle of the input power pulses is 50%. In our work, the beam width (spot size) was 0.7 mm and the beam divergence of the laser was less than 2.5 mrad. The speed that the beam was moved at in these experiments is 12.82 mm/ms. The output power density of the laser was 5.07 W/cm2, which was measured by a laser power/energy meter (842-PE, Newport, USA).

In order to reduce the errors in data, the length of the POF specimen is constant at 45 cm. The two ends of the fiber were cut vertically with a knife heated at 90℃. Then the POF sample was fixed on the paper board and notches were made at the same position by the CO2 laser at the same time. The morphology of POF with notches was observed and recorded using an optical microscope (Leica M165C, Leica Microsystems Ltd, Germany). Figure 1 shows a micrograph of the profile of a typical POF with a surface pattern, clearly revealing the shape and basic size of one notch. The height h equals 98.3 µm, and the angle 2δ is 148.2°. Four kinds of sample were prepared, which have zero, one, two or three patterns, respectively. The space between two neighboring notches is 1 mm. Figure 1.
Micrograph of polymer optical fiber with one notch.

sec.title: Transmission and side-emission light measurement
sec.p:
Series of cylindrical mandrels were used to simulate different bending radius, with the radius ranging from 2 to 16 mm. The bare POFs were wound half turns onto cylindrical mandrels of different radii and the notch was always kept on the outer curvature. The detailed experimental setup is shown in Figure 2. A 650 nm LED light source (LP-226, Linpu Instrument Ltd, China) was connected at one end of a POF using a fiber coupler (NBG-FC250, Fiber Plus International, Pennsylvania, USA), while the other end was plugged into a power meter (Fiber Optic Power Meter, FPM-800) using the other fiber coupler. The output power was recorded when the POFs with notches were bent at various bending radiuses. At the same time, an optical meter (Optometer P9710, Gigahertz-Optik, Germany) was used to record the power density of the side-emitting light at the site of notches. In all cases, the entrance of the bend is placed just after the fiber input, where the launching conditions are kept constant, in order to have the same input conditions at the entrance of the fiber bent section. The results were averaged for eight POF samples. The morphology of the POF with notches was observed and recorded using microscopy (Leica M165C, Leica Microsystems Ltd, Germany). Figure 2.
Experimental setup for the measurement of transmission light and side-emitting light.

sec.title: Light distribution of bent POF
sec.p:
To probe the power distribution of the normal POF in our experiment, the power distribution was observed in the cross-section of the POF with r = 125 µm. Figure 3 shows the experiment setup used to observe the power distribution in the cross-section of the POF. The end face of the POF was polished firstly. Then, the POF was fixed by adhesive tape on to the cylindrical mandrels with different radii. Finally, the power was launched into the POF by a LED, and the end face was observed using the microscope. Figure 3.
Experiment setup for observation of power distribution on the fiber cross-section.

sec.title: Fabrication and characterization of POF fabric
sec.p: The POF fabrics were woven from POF and PES using an Air-jet terry weaving machine (DORNIER, Germany). The fabric structure was plain weave. PES multifilament yarns of 100 D were selected for the warp yarns and the weft yarns were POFs of 250 µm diameter. Tension control was applied so that the weft POFs remained straight in the woven fabrics. The warp and weft yarn densities were 50 yarns/cm and 26 filaments/cm, respectively. Designed patterns were created on the POF fabrics using a computer-controlled CO2 laser.

The fabric was embedded in resin and sliced to observe the condition of POF in the fabric using an optical microscopy (Leica M165C, Leica Microsystems Ltd, Germany). The POF fabrics were wrapped onto cylindrical mandrels with different radii. The power density of the side-emitting light of POF fabric was measured using an optical power meter (Optometer P9710, Gigahertz-Optik, Germany).

sec.title: Theoretical model of light propagation in polymer optical fiber with notches
sec.p:
When light, travelling through the notched fiber, hits one face of the notch, two situations happen. A part of the light rays could be refracted out from the fiber to the air because these light rays cannot satisfy the total reflection condition in the POF. The other part of the light rays is reflected by the face of the notch and transmitted back to the end of the fiber. The amount of light reflected and light refracted primarily depends on the shape of the notch, the incident angle and the refraction indices of both the fiber core and the medium contacted with core. The light propagation in the POF with notches is shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Light propagation in the polymer optical fiber with a notch.

Furthermore, the other phenomenon that happens is that the light power tends to distribute in the convex side of the bending curve, when the POF is bent.31 Moreover, more significant convergence of light can be noticed on the convex fiber side with the bending radius becomes smaller and smaller.32

In our previous work, characteristics of a strain sensor based on the POF with similar notches were studied.33,34 The theoretical model was built up to analyze the relationship between the strain and the transmission power. The change of strain applied on the fiber results in the change of bending radius at the place of the notch.

In this model, the light rays reaching the face of the notch are totally reflected back according to the geometry analysis. There is no light ray refracting out when the notch considered is a V-groove, whose angle δ is about 148.2°. Even if the POF with notches is bent, there is no side emission. Therefore, the reduction of transmission light could be attributed to the reflected light on the face of the notch. The amount of reflected light also varies when the bending radius changes.

Figure 5(a) shows the situation of the POF with notches before and after bending and the distribution of light power. Comparing with the straight POF, the angle of the notches is larger for the bent POF. Total incident light power, P, can be divided into two parts: light that came to the notch, Pr, and light transmitted directly, Pd. To simplify calculations it is assumed that (i) the surface of the notch is smooth; (ii) the power of light is uniformly distributed across the whole or part of cross-section of the fiber. The proportion of power distribution on the total cross-sectional area is assumed as η because of uneven distribution of power in the bent fiber. Figure 5.
(a) Light propagation in the polymer optical fiber (POF) with a notch before and after bending; (b) the cross-section of the bent POF.
The transmission power after the notch is expressed as (1)Ptrans=Pd
The power that comes to the notch is calculated as (2)Pr={SbηπR2·P(Sb≤πR2/2)P(Sb>πR2/2)

The power that transmits directly is expressed as (3)Pd=P-Pr where R is the radius of the POF and Sb is the projection area of the notch on the cross-section of the POF. According to the geometrical relationship shown in Figure 5(b), Sb can be expressed as (4)Sb=12·R2·arccos(R-hbR)-(R-hb)·2Rhb-hb2
Assuming the notch face is not changed during bending, |P1G|=|P2G|. Hence (5)hcosδ=hbcosα

In the triangle ΔP2GOb, α can be calculated according to cosine theorem |P2G|2+|P2Ob|2-|GOb|2=2·|P2G|·|P2Ob|·cosα, (6)α=arccos(((hcosδ)2+(Rb+R)2-(Rb+R-h)2) ×cosδ2h(Rb+R)) where Rb is the bending radius of the POF and h and 2δ are the height and angle, respectively, of notches on the POF.

According to Equations (4)–(6), it is found that Sb can be described as the function of bending radius, Rb. The proportion of power distribution on the cross-section of bent POF, η, is also the function of Rb referred to in the above experimental analysis. Hence the transmission power, Ptrans, can also be expressed as the function of bending radius, Rb.
In the case of multiple notches, the transmission power after the first notch is expressed as (7)Ptrans1=Pd1 where (8)Pr1={SbηπR2·P(Sb≤πR2/2)P(Sb>πR2/2) (9)Pd1=P-Pr1
Similarly, the transmission power after the ith notch is (10)Ptransi=Pdi where (11)Pri={SbηπR2·Pt(i-1)(Sb≤πR2/2)Pt(i-1)(Sb>πR2/2) (12)Pdi=P-Pri

sec.title: Transmission and side emission of bent POF with notches
sec.p:
The transmission power of straight POF without notches, P, was measured as total incident light power. The ratio between the transmission power of the POF, Ptrans, and the total incident power is defined as the normalized transmission power. The ratio between the side emission power of the POF with notches, Pemit, and the total incident power is defined as the normalized transmission power. Figure 6 shows the measured normalized transmission power as the function of the bending radius. For POFs without notches, the normalized transmission power is 1.0 for a bending radius greater than or equal to 6 mm. This means that the loss is very low. As the bending radius is reduced below 6 mm, more light is refracted out of the fiber. For this reason, the normalized transmission power decreases too. When the bending radius is 2 mm, approximately 10% of the transmission power is lost by refraction into air. Figure 6.
Normalized transmission power as a function of bending radius for polymer optical fiber (POF) with and without notches (POF-0: POF without notch; POF-1: POF with one notch; POF-2: POF with two notches; POF-3: POF with three notches).

The normalized transmission power is much smaller for a notched POF at the same curvature than that without the notches. It is reduced when adding the number of notches on the POF surface. It is approximately 0.8 with one notch and then 0.65 with two notches when the bending radius is 16 mm. The transmission power also decreases with the decreasing bending radius for the POF with notches. Moreover, with the V-shaped notch, the transmission power slowly decreases with the decreasing bending radius even when the bending radius is greater than 6 mm, which is very similar to the result without the notch. The transmission power decreases sharply when the bending radius is smaller than 6 mm. This reveals that the presence of the notch changes the propagation of the light and makes less light transmit to the end of the POF. The light not transmitted to the end of the POF may be reflected to the end of incidence or be refracted out into the air from the notch.

To further understanding the effect of the notch on the light propagation, the power of side-emitting light was also measured when the bending radius changed. Figure 7 shows the relationship of the normalized side emission power and bending radius. The side-emitting light accounts for a very small part of the total incident light. The percentage of the side-emitting light is just about 0.2% for the POF with three notches when the bending radius is 16 mm. Along with the decrease of the bending radius, the side-emitting light power increased very slowly. In particular, the side-emitting light power remains nearly constant for the POF with one notch. There is some visible enhancement for the side-emitting light of the POF with more than one notch as the bending curvature increases. The side-emitting light power also increased with the number of notches. However, for the POF with the same notch, the increase of side-emitting light is far less than the decrease of transmission light as the bending radius decreases. This illuminates that bending of the POF hardly affects the side-emitting light of the POF with this kind of notch. It is likely that the light reflected by the notch face increases as the POF is gradually bent. It is also noticeable that the measured side-emitting light power is smaller than the real value, because the flat optical detector cannot catch all light emitting from the notch part of the bent POF. Figure 7.
Normalized side emission power as a function of bending radius for polymer optical fibers (POFs) with different numbers of notches (POF-1: POF with one notch; POF-2: POF with two notches; POF-3: POF with three notches).

Individual POFs bent at various curvatures were observed when the 650 nm light was incident in the POFs with different notches, which is shown in Figure 8. It is obvious that the location of the notch is brighter than other places on the POF, which reveals that the light leaks out from notch of the POF. The whole POF becomes brighter with the decrease of the bending radius because of macro-bending loss. However, the luminance of the notch barely changes with the variation of bending radius, no matter how many notches there are. The increase of the number of notches only extends the light emission area. The observed luminous phenomenon of the POF with notches is similar to the results given in Figure 7. Figure 8.
Light emitting from polymer optical fiber (POF) with different numbers of notches at various bending radii of 3, 5, 8 and 16 mm, respectively. (a)–(d): one notch; (e)–(h): two notches; (i)–(l): three notches.

sec.title: Verification of theoretical calculation
sec.p:
The relationship between the normalized transmission power and the bending radius was numerically simulated based on the theoretical modeling in the previous section. The height h equals 98.3 µm, and the angle 2δ is 148.2°. The light distribution on the cross-section of the bent POF was observed by optical microscopy and is shown in Figure 9. As shown in Figure 10, the light is uniformly distributed across the whole cross-section of the fiber when the bending radius is more than 3 mm. When the bending radius is smaller than 3 mm, the light converges to the convex side of the fiber and is only uniformly distributed in part of the cross-section of the fiber. It is estimated that the proportion of power distribution on the total cross-sectional area, η, is 30%, 50% and 70%, respectively, when the bending radiuses are 2, 2.5 and 3 mm. Figure 9.
Light distribution at the cross-section of polymer optical fiber (POF) when 650 nm light is propagated. The bending radii are 2, 2.5, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12.5 and 16 mm from (a) to (j), respectively.
Figure 10.
Calculated and measured normalized transmission power as a function of bending radius for polymer optical fiber (POF) with and without notches (POF-1: POF with one notch; POF-2: POF with two notches; POF-3: POF with three notches).

Using the above values, the simulation was carried out and results are shown in Figure 10. The transmission power varies with bending radius, Rb. The transmission power slowly reduces with the decrease of the bending radius until the bending radius reaches 3 mm, and then it decreases sharply as the bending radius decreases further. Moreover, the transmission power also decreases with the increasing number of notches. Comparing the results from the simulation with those from experiments, a good agreement is evident, especially when the bending radius is larger than 6 mm.

As shown in Figure 10, the simulated results for a bending radius of less than 3 mm are different from the experimental results. One possible reason is that we assume that the shape of the notch is an ideal obtuse V-groove and the surface of the notch is smooth. Hence the light cannot leak out from the fiber via the surface pattern. However, in fact there is a small amount of light radiated from the notch, which makes the transmission light decreases further. This happens because the surface of the notch is not completely smooth, and some irregularities of the surface result in the light leaking out. In addition, the light distribution in the cross-section of the bent POF was estimated on the basis of the experimental observed results. These results may not totally accord with the actual light distribution, because it is difficult to observe the exact status of light distribution in the bent POF, especially for the smaller bending radius. This also could cause the difference between the simulated Ptrans/P value and measured one, especially at smaller bending curvature.

sec.title: Luminous POF fabric
sec.p:
Woven POF fabrics are integrated with many parallel POFs, which are usually used for the screen matrix of displays or plane light sources because of the exact fiber arrangement and position determination. Varying degrees of crimping usually show in fabrics because of their flexible structure. Hence bending is inevitable for POFs integrated in any woven fabric. In order to investigate the side emission behavior of POF fabric, the woven POF fabric was fabricated, where POFs remain straight in the fabric to avoid macro-bending loss. The woven POF fabric was made from 250 µm POF and PES multifilament yarns of 100 D by an Air-jet terry weaving machine. In the plain woven fabric, POFs were straight, as shown in Figure 11. Figure 11.
Cross-section view of woven polymer optical fiber fabric.

An area of 50 mm × 30 mm on the surface of POF fabrics was treated by a CO2 laser to provoke light emission. All optical fiber ends were coupled together for input to the LED light. The light was incident from two ends of a POF. The power densities of side emission of bent POF fabrics were measured at different bending curvatures. Three individual measurements on the surface of fabric were taken on each bent condition and results were averaged. The relationship between power density and bending radius is shown in Figure 12. While the bending radius changes from 16 to 6 mm, there is only a small fluctuation for the power density of light-emitting POF fabric, similar to the behavior of single POF fabric with notches at different bending conditions. The insets of Figure 12 show the corresponding photos of light-emitting POF fabric at each bending radius. From these photos, it is obvious that the luminance of POF fabric is almost the same for different bending conditions. Hence the bending to some extent does not affect the light emission on the surface of POF fabric. However, sharp bending to an excessively large curvature should be avoided. The reason for this is that POF fabric is stiffer than traditional textiles and single POF fabric. Hard bending may break the POFs in the fabric. Figure 12.
Power density of side-emitting light from polymer optical fiber (POF) fabric surface as a function of bending radius. The insets are the corresponding photographs of bent luminous POF fabrics.

Incorporated with a green LED light source, power source and other electronic components, POF fabrics can present designed patterns on the surface. Figure 13 shows a woven POF fabric treated with CO2 laser, displaying the designed patterns. The flexible fabric is very thin and quite lightweight. The introduction of the CO2 laser treating method can simplify the fabrication of POF fabric display and can be applied to various POF fabrics. Figure 13.
Designed pattern display by woven polymer optical fiber fabric treated with a CO2 laser.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In summary, the transmission and side-emission behavior of POF fabric with notches bent at various curvatures were studied. The experimental results show that the transmission light decreased with decreasing bending radius, as well as increasing the number of notches. The side-emitting light only accounted for a very small part of the total incident light and had little effect, while the bending radius varied from 6 to 16 mm. Theoretical analysis of the relationship between transmission light and bending radius was conducted: the results matched with the experimental results. The decrease of transmission light was ascribed to the reflected light at the face of the notches, which increased with reducing bending radius. The side-emitting light from the notch zone was not affected by the bending condition of the POF. The side emission of woven POF fabric treated by laser at different bent conditions was also studied. A similar result has been obtained with that of POF with notches. Woven POF fabric displays were manufactured with the help of a computer-controlled CO2 laser to exhibit the designed patterns.

ack.p: Shen Jing gratefully acknowledges a postgraduate scholarship received from Institute of Textiles and Clothing, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University.

sec.p: This research has been supported by Innovation and Technology Fund of Hong Kong SAR Government (Grant No. GHP/043/07TP).
